The selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) is a well-established technology for controlling NO x emissions from industrial sources. FeO x -based catalysts have been extensively studied due to their favorable thermal stability, natural abundance, environmental compatibility, and effective deNO x performance under ideal conditions. However, the presence of SO2 in actual flue gases poses a significant barrier to the widespread commercial adoption of the FeO x -based catalysts. During the reaction process, SO2 interacts with NH3 or catalyst active sites, leading to the formation of ammonia bisulfate/sulfate (NH4HSO4/(NH4)2SO4) and relatively inert metal sulfates. These byproducts are the primary causes of the observed decline in NO x conversion efficiency, underscoring the critical need to develop next-generation catalysts with enhanced SO2 resistance. This review provides a comprehensive overview of recent advancements in FeO x -based catalysts for the SCR reactions in SO2-containing environments. The process of SO2 adsorption on Fe2O3 is first summarized, as it represents the initial step in catalyst sulfur deactivation. When SO2 interacts with NH₃ or active catalyst components, the resulting ammonium sulfates or metal sulfates can either enhance or impair catalytic performance, a topic explored in detail later. Given that H2O is a common component in industrial flue gases, its role in accelerating catalyst deactivation alongside SO2 is also clarified. To address this significant deactivation challenge, established strategies for improving the SO2 resistance of SCR catalysts are discussed in Section 5. While these approaches can slow deactivation, they cannot prevent it entirely. Therefore, Section 6 covers advances in regenerating spent catalysts for recycling and reuse. Finally, this review highlights the urgent need for further improvements in catalyst durability under real-world flue gas conditions to achieve more efficient and sustainable NO x emission control. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords SCR FeOx-based catalysts Metal sulfate Ammonia bisulfate/sulfate SO2 resistance Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (abbreviated as NO x , comprising NO and NO2) are major atmospheric pollutants originating from both stationary and mobile sources, posing significant threats to public health and regional air quality [1,2]. In response to this pressing environmental challenge, China implemented the national “Emission Standard of Air Pollutants for Thermal Power Plants” (GB 13,223–2011), setting the NO x emission limit at below 100 mg/m3 [3]. In 2014, the introduction of ultra-low emission standards further tightened this limit to 50 mg/m3, demanding more effective technologies to curb NO x emissions [4]. Additionally, regulations mandate a 10 % reduction in total NO x emissions by 2025 compared to 2020 levels [5]. Several emerging technologies, such as plasma-assisted catalysis, photocatalysis, and selective non-catalytic reduction (SNCR), have shown promise [6–8]. However, their widespread adoption has been limited by drawbacks like unwanted byproduct formation, low NO x removal efficiency, and high operating costs. The selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) stands out as a mature and widely adopted engineering solution for NO x abatement [9,10]. As the key component in this technology, the activity of the catalysts predominantly determines the NO x removal efficiency of the entire system. Currently, V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 composites are the industry standard catalysts for NO x reduction in power plants due to their high activity and N₂ selectivity within the 300–400 °C temperature range [11]. However, limitations such as the toxicity of V2O5, the suboptimal low-temperature performance (<300 °C), and the tendency to oxidize SO2 to SO3, hinder their broader application [12]. Consequently, research has increasingly shifted towards vanadium-free catalysts to develop more efficient and environmentally benign alternatives. Transition metal oxides, including MnO x , CuO x and FeO x , have been extensively investigated for the SCR reactions owing to their natural abundance, satisfactory stability, oxidative versatility, and tunable microstructures [13–17]. When combined with other materials, MnO x -based catalysts exhibit enhanced low-temperature NO x removal efficiency and improved N2 selectivity [18,19]. Meanwhile, other catalysts demonstrate effective NO x reduction in medium-to-high temperature ranges [20–24]. Additionally, their anti-poisoning capability, a critical factor in assessing practical applicability, can also be significantly enhanced [25,26] (Table 1 ). Of these, FeO x has garnered significant attention due to its variable reactive oxygen species, ease of forming surface vacancies, and eco-friendly properties, making it highly suitable for the SCR processes. To enhance FeO x ’s deNO x performance, researchers have employed diverse strategies, such as synthesis optimization and chemical modification [27,28]. Whether used as active components, promoters, supports, or part of mixed oxides, FeO x -based catalysts consistently demonstrate high NO x conversion efficiency and N2 selectivity across a wide temperature range [9,29–31]. These advantages have fueled a surge in studies exploring FeO x -based catalysts for NO x reduction, covering synthesis methods, SCR performance, poison resistance, and reaction mechanisms. Over the past decades, a wealth of research papers, communications, and reviews have been published on this topic, collectively suggesting that FeO x -based materials could serve as viable replacements for V2O5-based catalysts in industrial applications [32]. However, the real-world flue gases invariably contain SO2, with concentrations ranging from tens to thousands of parts per million (ppm). While FeO x -based catalysts demonstrate greater resistance to SO2 (or SO2+H2O mixtures) compared to MnO x -, CeO x -, or CuO x -based catalysts in most cases, SO2’s interactions with FeO x can still reduce NO x conversion efficiency and lead to catalyst deactivation, especially at low to medium temperature ranges [33–36]. To mitigate this issue, researchers have investigated how SO2 affects the physicochemical and catalytic properties of FeO x -based materials. Leveraging these insights, modifications to the catalysts’ textural and chemical properties have been explored to enhance their stability in SO2-rich environments, thereby improving their practicality [37,38]. Despite these advances, a systematic review of SO2’s interaction mechanisms with FeO x -based catalysts, along with the strategies to counteract its detrimental effects, remains lacking. Given this gap and the promising progress in the field, a comprehensive summary of FeO x -based catalysts’ SO2 durability is both timely and critically important. This review highlights the recent advancements in the SO2 resistance of the FeO x -based catalysts (Fig. 1 ). First, the adsorption of SO2 on Fe2O3 is examined, as this process initiates the catalyst’s performance degradation. Next, the interaction mechanisms between SO2 and FeO x -based catalysts are analyzed, with a focus on the diverse sulfate species formed during reactions emphasized. Given that H2O is a common component of real flue gases, its role in accelerating SO2-induced catalyst deactivation is also explored. To address these challenges, established strategies for improving SO2 tolerance are summarized. Although these strategies can slow catalyst deactivation, complete prevention still remains challenging. For recycling and reusing the spent catalysts, progresses on the regeneration of the poisoned catalysts are illustrated in the sixth section. Finally, the review concludes with perspectives on further enhancing catalyst durability under real-world flue gas conditions. 2 SO2 adsorption on Fe2O3 When investigating the adsorption behaviors of SO2 on Fe2O3, the detailed adsorption sites and the generated adsorbed species should be clearly discovered. Generally, the former information could be uncovered through the combination of density functional theory (DFT) and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) methods, while the latter information was demonstrated mainly via the in situ DRIFTS characterization. From the projected density of state (PDOS) results, the appearance of some hybrid density peaks between the d orbits of Fe and the p orbits of O verified the fact that the adsorption of SO2 onto the γ-Fe2O3 (001) surface was a chemisorption process [39]. Herein, certain sites must be involved in the SO2 adsorption process, with the formation of chemical bonds accompanying. To reveal this knowledge, Jin et al. supposed that SO2 molecules could be adsorbed on the Fe2O3 surface through binding to two Fe atoms by its two O atoms (Fe2O3-SO2-I) or two Fe atoms by its two O atoms and one O atom of Fe2O3 by its S atom (Fe2O3-SO2-II) [40]. Compared with the original SO2 molecules, the S-O intramolecular bond elongated and the S-O bond angle also changed when SO2 was adsorbed on the Fe2O3 surface. Simultaneously, the O atoms bound to the Fe atoms, revealing the strong interactions between SO2 and the surface atoms of Fe2O3. The SO2 adsorption energy of the abovementioned two systems was calculated to follow the order of Fe2O3-SO2-II (−3.63 eV) < Fe2O3-SO2-I (−2.30 eV), suggesting that Fe2O3-SO2-II was the stable configuration for SO2 adsorption on Fe2O3 (Fig. 2 (a)). And due to the strong electron affinity of the S = O bonds, the electron transfer path was illustrated as Fe → O → S [41]. Differently, Ren et al. demonstrated three SO2 adsorption configurations and two SO3 adsorption configurations on the γ-Fe2O3 (001) surface (Fig. 2(b)) [42]. The adsorption energies of the three SO2 adsorption configurations are −21.762 kJ/mol, −70.827 kJ/mol, and −45.212 kJ/mol, demonstrating that the configuration related to two atoms connected with two octahedral Fe cations can effectively elucidate the SO2 adsorption process over Fe2O3. Coupled with its shorter Fe-O bond length than the Fe-S bond length, SO2 showed a tendency to be closer to the adsorption surface with O-terminal. When SO2 was adsorbed on the surface active site using the S-end, it would lose electrons, and when it approached the O-end, it would get electrons, owing to the strong electronegativity and oxidation of O atoms. Given the presence of O2 in flue gas, a certain amount of SO3 would be generated despite the comparatively low conversion efficiency (usually <10 %). When adsorbed onto the Fe2O3 surface, two configurations were supposed. In configuration (a), two O atoms of SO3 were bonded to two octahedral Fe atoms adjacent to the surface. While in configuration (b), S atom in SO3 is connected to a lattice oxygen and two O atoms are linked to two Fe atoms. Based on the adsorption energies of SO3, it seems that configuration (b) could clearly clarify the adsorption behavior of SO3 on the Fe2O3 surface. And during the SO3 adsorption process, SO3 would combine with lattice oxygen in Fe2O3 to form sulfate-like species and lose some electrons under the action of lattice oxygen. Despite the diverse SO2 adsorption configurations reported in the literature, the Fe cations and O anions, which always functioned as the redox sites, were considered to be responsible for SO2 adsorption. Considering that the lattice models used during the DFT analysis always lack vacancies or surface hydroxyls, some critical information, like the additional SO2 adsorption sites, was neglected in some cases. As H2O was present in feed gases, H2O molecules adsorbed on catalysts would be transformed to surface hydroxyl groups (-OH). Thanks to their amphoteric features, -OH could also be responsible for the adsorption of SO2, as shown in the following equation [43]. (1) − O H + S O 2 ( g ) → S O 3 2 − + H 2 O Through the interactions between SO2 and Fe/O sites or surface hydroxyl groups, S-containing species are primarily present in the forms of surface- and bulk-like sulfate, bisulfate, sulfite, and bisulfite species, as evidenced by the appearance of the IR characteristic peaks located at 900–1200 cm-1, ∼1287 cm-1, ∼1360 cm-1, ∼1470 cm-1, and ∼1550 cm-1 [40,44]. At lower temperatures, along with the above-mentioned species, parts of SO2 were also physisorbed onto the catalyst surface. As the temperature rose, surface bidentate sulfates became pronounced, with physisorbed SO2, bisulfate, bisulfite, and sulfite species gradually diminishing. When the temperature exceeded 350 °C, surface bidentate sulfates were the main S-containing functional groups, probably stemming from their higher thermal stability than the other species [45]. Usually, the decomposition of bidentate sulfate species occurred at temperatures of >500 °C, evident in the appearance of the derived DTG peaks in this temperature range [46,47]. Based on these findings, the stabilization of Fe sites by sulfate anions and their superior thermal stability highlight the inevitable effects of SO2 on the SCR performance of the catalysts, either the promotional or the detrimental impacts. Thus, the advances in the effects of SO2 would be summarized in the subsequent sections. 3 SO2 affecting mechanisms It is well accepted that the reaction temperature determines the existing forms of the generated sulfate species to a considerable extent. At lower temperatures, ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4) and ammonium bisulfate (NH4HSO4) are formed through the reactions among O2, NH3, H2O, and SO2 [48]. While both compounds contribute to deactivation, NH4HSO4 is particularly problematic because it remains stable while (NH4)2SO4 decomposes below 250 °C, releasing gaseous NH3 [49]. As temperatures increase, NH4HSO4 decomposes, leaving sulfate anions stabilized by the FeO x species. The as-generated metal sulfates then become the primary deactivating agents. Understanding these temperature-dependent mechanisms is crucial for optimizing FeO x -based catalysts for industrial applications. 3.1 Deposition of NH4HSO4 At lower temperature points, the deposition of ammonia bisulfate is recognized as one of the critical reasons for the declined NO x conversion of the FeO x -based catalysts. Unlike the powder state of ammonia sulfate, ammonia bisulfate always exists in a liquid state at temperatures of >147 °C [50,51]. The sticky and corrosive properties make liquid-state ammonia bisulfate tend to cover the active sites and block the pore structures of the catalysts. From microscopic perspectives, the spatial network of ammonia bisulfate makes the open space above the isolated metal cations, which function as the active components during the SCR reactions, decrease from 0.47 nm to 0.23 nm, smaller than the diameters of the NH3 (0.37 nm) and NO (0.32 nm) molecules. This decline hinders the mass transfer of the reactant molecules towards the active sites, thereby adversely affecting the deNO x reactions [52]. Apart from the blockage effect, the strong interaction between metal cations and ammonia bisulfate constitutes another critical factor interfering with the SCR reactions. Specifically, HSO4 - in ammonia bisulfate tends to interact with metal cations, forming metal sulfate-like compounds [53]. This stabilization would exert a negative effect on the adsorption and activation of the reactant molecules, even though the sulfate-bonded metal cations can be varied depending on their diverse affinities to sulfate species. Generally, the deposition of ammonia bisulfate easily occurs for the VO x -based catalysts owing to their strong oxidation capability of SO2 to SO3 and during the heating process, the decomposition of NH4 + was discovered to occur prior to that of sulfate anions [54,55]. While for the FeO x -based catalysts, relatively low amounts of literatures are available. Through the density functional theory, it was found that during the decomposition process, one of the NH bonds in NH4 + broke to form NH3, which was easily attracted by the nearby octahedral Fe cation active sites, with stable coordination adsorbed NH3 formed and sulfate species remaining on the Fe2O3 catalyst surface [42]. The activation energy of NH4 + decomposition was calculated to be 50.648 kJ/mol, similar to that of most catalysts displaying during the SCR reactions. This level can be ascribed to one hydrogen bond existing between one of the H atoms in NH4 + and the surface lattice oxygen, which was affected by the O anions. Therefore, when breaking NH bond, only a small amount of energy was required to be absorbed. Furthermore, the comparatively high activation energy related to the decomposition of sulfate anions clearly confirmed their strong interaction with Fe2O3, with Fe-SO4-like compounds formed as the product. Coupled with the studies from other researchers, the decomposition of ammonia bisulfate can be categorized into three steps: (a) release of H2O by direct decomposition of NH4HSO4; (b) consumption of NH3 by either direct decomposition of NH4 + or its reaction with NO x , with sulfate species stabilized by the metal cations; (c) release of SO2 through the direct decomposition of SO4 2-, as demonstrated by the following four equations [56–58]. (2) − N H 4 H S O 4 → − S O 3 − N H 3 + H 2 O ( g ) (3) − S O 3 − N H 3 → − S O 3 + N H 3 ( g ) (4) − S O 3 − N H 3 + N O x ( g ) → − S O 3 + N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) (5) − S O 3 → S O 2 ( g ) + O 2 ( g ) Given its thermodynamically favorable properties, the generation of ammonia bisulfate is recognized as an inevitable problem, even though the reaction of NH4 + with NO and O2 could limit the continuous buildup of ammonia bisulfate and establish a dynamic deposition-consumption equilibrium [59]. Considering that most FeO x -based catalysts are operating in medium- and high-temperature ranges, the deposition of NH4HSO4 may not be the critical reason to explain the deactivation phenomena occurring with SO2. Instead, the reaction between SO2 and active FeO x species forming metal sulfates may somehow elucidate the reasons for the varying deNO x performances of the catalysts, in which the recent advances would be extensively summarized in the subsequent sections. 3.2 Formation of metal sulfate Through the combination of experimental methods and density functional theory (DFT) techniques, it was revealed that for Fe2O3, the significant sulfur deactivation was primarily caused by the formation of stable inert metal sulfates instead of the accumulation of ammonia bisulfate on the catalyst surface, particularly at medium and high temperatures [60]. Therefore, most attention should be focused on the FeO x -SO2 reactions in investigating the sulfur deactivation problem of the FeO x -based catalysts, similar with other vanadium-free catalysts, like the CeO x - and MnO x -based systems [61]. When operating in the SO2-containing working gas, dual effects of SO2 are always observed on the SCR performances of the FeO x -based catalysts, namely the positive and negative effects. Depending on the physicochemical properties of the catalysts and the reaction temperature, the types and amounts of the accumulated metal sulfates are always diverse, hence bringing out varying impacts. 3.2.1 Positive effects Generally, the adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst surface initiates the SCR reactions [11]. With SO2, the formation of metal species would create abundant acid sites on the catalyst surface, which promotes the adsorption of NH3 and increases the availability of the adsorbed ammonia species for the subsequent activation step to reduce NO x , thereby facilitating the progression of the deNO x reactions, particularly at medium- and high-temperature points [62,63]. This is because a relatively high reaction temperature could provide sufficient energy to activate the reactants, making the oxidizability a secondary factor in determining the SCR performance of the catalysts. Simultaneously, a high reaction temperature would induce a loss of surface NH3 coverage, meaning that the acidity of the catalysts becomes a major factor in their high-temperature NO x conversion [1]. Specifically, the accumulated sulfate species are primarily present in the form of bidentate sulfates under humidity conditions, in which the S = O bonds could be broken under the action of H2O molecules and combine with H atoms forming S-OH bonds, the typical Brønsted acid sites [64–66]. The advances in the promotional effects on the SCR performance are summarized in the following table (Table 2). Unlike the comparatively poor high-temperature deNO x performance demonstrated by the pristine γ-Fe2O3, the sulfation process increases its conversion to ∼100 % across the temperature range of 350–400 °C. Alongside the enhanced NH3 adsorption, the sites for -NH2 adsorption and the activation components for -NH2 oxidation were separated after the sulfation process, which reduced the ability of Fe3+ for -NH2 oxidation to NO Coupled with the decreased concentration of Fe3+, most NH3 was prone to functioning as the reductant to reduce NO x rather than directly converting to NO x [67]. On this basis, the Fe-Ti spinel compound was obtained through the incorporation of Ti into γ-Fe2O3, aiming to increase the deNO x performance of the Fe2O3 catalyst with or without SO2. Similar with the pristine γ-Fe2O3, the weakened oxidizability, together with the enhanced acidity, arising from the sulfation process hindered the proceeding of the undesired side reactions related to NH3 over-oxidation to NO x . With the guidance of the formed sulfate species, the Fe-Ti spinel displayed similar high-temperature activity with the commercialized V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst (V2O5 content: 2 wt %), with >90 % NO x conversion achieved at temperatures of 350–450 °C [68]. Except for the enhancement in the high-temperature deNO x performance of the above-mentioned catalysts, the introduced sulfate species could increase the NO x conversion of the Fe2O3/TiO2 supported catalyst at both medium and high temperatures. Unlike <75 % NO x conversion presented by the fresh catalyst, the sulfated samples could eliminate >98 % of the NO x from the working gas within a temperature range of 350–450 °C and at 300 °C, the NO x conversion almost doubled relative to the fresh sample [69]. This was because the sulfate effect probably occurred on FeO x instead of TiO2, which brought out more dispersed iron phase and strong Brønsted acid sites, thereby enhancing the adsorption of NH3 and facilitating the proceeding of the NO x reduction reaction. Similar phenomena were also observed for the thermally deactivated Fe2(SO4)3/TiO2 catalysts. Due to the decomposition of Fe2(SO4)3 during the thermal deactivation process, α-Fe2O3 particles were formed, accompanied by the reduced quantity of Brønsted acid sites, hence causing a decline in NO x conversion from 90 % to 60 % at 350 °C. SO2 treatment would reverse this phase transformation and ultimately lead to the recovery of Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 3 (a)). Apparently, the regenerated sample displayed similar NO x conversion with the fresh Fe2(SO4)3/TiO2 catalyst [70]. Interestingly, for α-Fe2O3 nanosheet (Fe2O3 NS) and nanorod (Fe2O3 NR), the introduction of SO2 elevated their deNO x performances across the whole investigated temperature range. Under the action of SO2, the NO x conversion of Fe2O3 NS exceeded 75 % between 300 and 350 °C, outperforming the fresh one (<50 % NO x conversion from 150–400 °C). Further, a noticeable enhancement in SCR performance occurred for the nanosheet-shaped one, with ∼100 % NO x conversion achieved within 275–400 °C. This improvement was mainly ascribed to the exposed (110) facet of the nanorod-structured catalyst, which showed comparatively high reactivity in NH3 activation despite the presence of SO2. Simultaneously, the Fe2O3 nanorod also displayed a greater affinity to SO2, meaning that sulfate species were easily formed on the surface. Upon serving as the Brønsted acid sites for the sufficient adsorption of NH3, the efficient proceeding of the SCR reactions was ensured (Fig. 3(b)) [71]. Moreover, the degree of sulfation was found to determine the SCR activity of the sulfated Fe2O3 catalysts [72]. Given an increase in temperature, the degree of surface sulfation was deepened and the states of sulfate species on Fe2O3 changed from surface species to bulk-like ones. Compared with the bulk-like sulfates (>85 % NO x conversion between 300 and 350 °C), the surface sulfates displayed higher SCR activity, with >85 % NO x conversion achieved in a temperature range of 250–375 °C. The increased number of acid sites, coupled with the retained oxidative ability, facilitated the proceeding of the Eley-Rideal pathway, thereby enhancing the deNO x performance of the catalysts (Fig. 3(c)). Given the continuous improvement of acidity and the gradual reduction in oxidizability during sulfation, the previously indicated phenomena can be probably explained by reaching an acidity-oxidizability balance at an appropriate sulfation degree. When deviating this optimal degree, catalyst’s deNO x performance would display a downward tendency owing to the excessively weak or strong oxidative ability. Even if the positive effects of SO2 can bring out an improved SCR performance either in specific or entire investigated temperature range, the relevant catalysts exhibit limited deNO x performances under ideal conditions. Specifically, comparatively good deNO x performance, probably >85 % NO x conversion, can only be achieved in a narrow temperature window. That is to say, these findings remain largely theoretical. Conversely, for those highly active catalysts in “clean” working gas, negative effects are usually displayed, which pose significant barriers to industrialization. Therefore, these challenges would be extensively demonstrated in the following section. 3.2.2 Negative effects Unlike the promotional effects occurring at medium- and high-temperatures, the negative effects are always observed at lower temperatures, particularly <250 °C. Herein, the deposition of ammonia bisulfate always accompanies. Considering that ammonia bisulfate can be gradually consumed through their reaction with NO x , the interactions between SO2 and FeO x might explain the deactivation of the catalysts to a considerable extent [74]. The deactivation mechanisms could be categorized into three aspects: (1) inhibited mass transfer of the reactant molecules stemming from the decreased specific surface area and pore volume, (2) weakened oxidative ability arising from the formation relative inert metal sulfates, (3) inhibiting the formation of active nitrate/nitrite species from the SO2 NO competitive adsorption on the catalyst surface active sites [34,75]. The advances in the detrimental effects on the SCR performance of the typically reported catalysts are summarized in the following table (Table 3). Through the reaction between the active components and SO2, the accumulated sulfate species would block the pore structures, particularly the ones with smaller diameters. Apparently, the specific surface area displayed a downward trend and the average pore diameter would be enlarged [75,85,86]. Depending on the amount of sulfate salts formed, the total pore volume of the catalysts could be either increased or decreased. Compared with the parameters of the total pore volume and average pore diameter, the role of the catalyst’s specific surface area seemed to be more pronounced during the catalytic reactions [2]. Specifically, the decreased specific surface area would lead to a reduced availability of catalyst surface acid sites and also make adverse impacts on the catalyst-reactant molecules interactions [12,31]. However, the textural structures are usually accepted as the secondarily important factors in determining the performance of the catalysts [31,87]. In other words, the decrease in specific surface area can only be the indirect reasons, rather than the direct ones, to explain the deactivation of the catalysts by SO2. Commonly accepted opinions are that the sulfation process caused an abundance of acid sites on the catalyst at the expense of both the reduced reducibility and availability of Fe3+ [32]. The latter reduction would inhibit the activation of the reactant molecules through the stabilization of Fe cations by sulfate anions. Simultaneously, the formation of metal sulfates might induce an excessive coverage of NH3 on the catalyst surface, making the reactant activation step negatively affected by NH3 adsorbed onto nearby acidic sites because of electronic interaction or possibly direct blocking of the redox sites. This “inhibition effect”, which has been discovered in metal oxide- and zeolite-based catalysts by some research groups and only occurs at lower temperatures, could explain the decreased activity of the catalyst with SO2 below 250 °C [86,88,89]. However, these opinions were overthrown for the FeCu/SSZ-13 catalyst. Specifically, partial Si-OH-Al bonds of the zeolite framework were broken to form Al2(SO4)3 under the action of SO2, which contributed to the decreased amount of Brønsted acid sites. Coupled with the weakened oxidative ability through the generation of relative inert CuSO4 and Fe2(SO4)3, the adsorption of NH3 and the activation of the adsorbed ammonia species to NH2 were simultaneously inhibited, which slowed down the formation of intermediate NH4NO2 and therefore exerted detrimental effects on NO x reduction [79]. By employing the in situ DRIFTS method, it was discovered that SO2 could be adsorbed on Fe and O sites as in the form of bidentate mononuclear sulfate, which would result in a reduction in NO adsorption and retard the formation of NO complex on the surface of the catalyst, like the active monodentate nitrates, thereby cutting off the proceeding of the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) pathway (Fig. 4 (a)) [34,90]. With the guidance of the temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) and NO x -temperature programmed desorption characterizations (NO x -TPD), SO2 treatment was discovered to reduce the generation of intermediates, including ammonia nitrite and ammonia nitrate, through the inhibition of NO x adsorption and nitrate/nitrite formation (Fig. 4(b)) [81]. From a microscopic perspective, the adsorption energy (Eads ) for NO and SO2 on pristine γ-Fe2O3 was calculated to be −2.853 eV and −1.605 eV, meaning that SO2 displayed a higher affinity to Fe sites than NO and also confirming the detrimental effects of SO2 on the adsorption of NO and the progression of the l-H pathway (Fig. 4(c)) [59]. Differently, Jin et al. found that the co-adsorption of NO and O2 could also be proceeded on sulfated Fe2O3 surface, with bidentate nitrate, -NO2 nitro, and monodentate nitrate species formed. Through their combination with ionic NH4 +, both E-R and l-H reaction pathways were obeyed during NO x reduction [40]. This difference may be attributed to the lower quantity of sulfate salts formed on the catalyst surface, leaving certain amounts of sites preserved for NO and O2 co-adsorption. Given that the balance of the acidity and oxidizability plays predominant roles in the SCR performances of the catalysts, the effects of SO2 on the proceeding of the deNO x reactions are primarily determined by either maintaining or breaking this balance [91,92]. Once this balance was reached under the action of SO2, particularly for the materials with weak acidity, like the pristine γ-Fe2O3 and the Fe2O3/TiO2 supported catalysts, a steady or even increased NO x conversion would be presented. While for the other catalysts with superior catalytic activity, the introduction of SO2 would weaken the oxidative ability, with enhanced or reduced acidity accompanying. That is to say, once the balance of the acidity and oxidizability was broken by SO2, the catalysts would suffer from severe sulfur deactivation. 4 Effects of H2O Water vapor (H2O), a major component in industrial exhaust gases and an SCR reaction product, can make adverse impacts on the deNO x performance of the catalysts. Even in dry conditions, the water vapor generated during the SCR reactions may partially impair catalytic activity, either through the reversible or irreversible effects [93]. The reversible effect primary stems from the competitive adsorption between H2O and NH3/NO, with catalytic activity typically recovering upon H2O removal [94]. However, irreversible deactivation occurs when the decomposition of water vapor creates additional surface hydroxyl groups on the catalyst, requiring elevated temperatures for regeneration [95,96]. These negative effects are primarily observed at lower temperatures, while higher temperatures often mitigate or even enhance SCR activity [96]. In fact, the waste gases of almost all industrial processes required treatment contain water vapor. Numerous studies that have been conducted in the absence of H2O, do not reflect the reality of the application. Notably, from a fundamental point of view, these studies could help to evaluate and improve the catalysts for the SCR reactions. Compared with the conditions only containing SO2, the deactivation of the catalysts is more severe when SO2 and H2O are simultaneously present, demonstrating that SO2 and H2O appear to exhibit a synergistic toxicity in the poisoning of the catalysts [97]. With the increase in the reaction temperature, the deactivation of the catalysts becomes more serious, likely owing to the increase of SO2 oxidation rate to SO3, thus producing more metal sulfates. At higher temperatures, probably higher than 350 °C, the deactivation phenomena were gradually lessened [98]. Recent advances in the effects of water vapor on the sulfur resistance of the catalysts are summarized in Table 4 . For instance, ∼90 % NO x conversion was maintained within 6 h in the presence of 100 ppm SO2 for the H3PW12O40-modifed Fe2O3 catalyst. Once 5 % H2O and 100 ppm SO2 were co-introduced, only ∼46 % NO x conversion was obtained after the 6-hour deactivation cycle [99]. Also, minimal variations in NO x conversion were displayed in the presence of 470 ppm SO2 for the NdO x and H3PW12O40 co-doped Fe2O3 catalyst, while the co-presence of 470 ppm SO2 and 8 % H2O contributed to a decline in NO x conversion from ∼85 % to ∼55 % [100]. The detailed reasons could be categorized into three aspects. The first aspect is that the reactants of NO and NH3 experienced competitive adsorption behavior with water vapor. Specifically, the high affinity of H2O to the catalyst surface acid sites and redox sites could exert an inhibitory effect on NH3 and NO adsorption, probably leaving certain amounts of sites available for the adsorption of SO2 owing to its great affinity to Fe and O sites. The excessive coverage of sulfate species on the catalyst surface would further weaken the adsorption and activation of NO, hence interfering with the progression of the SCR reactions [101,102]. The second aspect can be attributed to the accelerated growth of surface hydroxyl groups, which functioned as the additional sites for SO2 adsorption. Under the action of O2, more sulfate species would be accumulated on the catalyst surface, either as ammonia bisulfate or metal sulfates [103]. The third aspect is that H2O would transform the structure of the sulfates and react with the reductant NH3 to form ammonia sulfate or ammonia bisulfate sediments, which cover the active sites or block the pore structures of the catalysts [104]. In other words, water vapor would function as a catalyst to accelerate the formation of ammonia sulfate or ammonia bisulfate, consequently bringing about the more significant deactivation effect [105]. 5 Strategies for improving SO2 resistance To boost SO2 resistance, researchers have developed catalyst modifications through both chemical composition optimization and structural design. Current approaches focus on four key strategies: (1) accelerating ammonia bisulfate decomposition, (2) suppressing SO2 adsorption, (3) incorporating sacrificial sites to shield active Fe centers, and (4) enhancing active nitrate species formation. This section examines recent progress in these approaches, with representative examples of improved sulfur-resistant catalysts summarized in the table below (Table 5). 5.1 Accelerating the decomposition of ammonia bisulfate Given that the decomposition of ammonia bisulfate accounts for the deactivation of the catalysts by SO2 at lower temperatures to a considerable extent, enhancing its decomposition behavior is proven as an effective strategy to elevate the anti-poisoning ability. Basically, the decomposition of ammonia bisulfate can be improved through the optimization of textural structures, chemical formula, synthesis methods, and gas components. Based on the fact that ammonia bisulfate usually exists in a liquid state in most cases and its evaporation temperature is closely related to the capillarity phenomena in mesopores, the decomposition of ammonia bisulfate could be effectively promoted through expanding the pore size of the catalysts. With increasing the pore size of the Fe2O3/SBA-15 catalysts from 4.8 to 11.8 nm, the ammonia bisulfate decomposition temperature displayed a tendency to decline from 384.1 to 343.3 °C with the guidance of the thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 5 (a)) [117]. Additionally, it was found that once ammonia bisulfate was deposited on the catalyst surface, the sulfate anions would interact with metal cations, forming the metal sulfate-like compound. Thus, it was reasonable to optimize the chemical formula of the catalysts to reduce the stability of the deposited ammonia bisulfate through changing the SO4 2--metal cation interactions [41,118]. Given that Fe2O3 cube was loaded onto the MoO3 nanobelt surface, NH4 + in ammonia bisulfate was initially intercalated into the interlayer of MoO3, leading to a NH4 +-HSO4 - cation-anion separation by conquering their strong electrostatic interactions. Subsequently, the separated NH4 + was consumed by taking part in low-temperature NH3-SCR. Simultaneously, the surface HSO4 - separated from ammonia bisulfate oxidized the reduced catalyst during the NH3-SCR cycle, concomitant with the release of SO2 gas, thus inducing the decomposition of NH4HSO4 [119]. And upon the addition of Ce additive, the activation energy for the decomposition of NH4HSO4, (NH4)2SO4, and H2SO4 over γ-Fe2O3 was decreased from 50.648 eV, 102.252 eV, and 443.376 eV to 42.568 eV, 65.164 eV, and 128.816 eV, respectively, which enabled the Ce-doped γ-Fe2O3 catalyst to display an enhanced SO2-tolerant ability (Fig. 5(b)) [42]. Through monitoring the effects of the deposited NH4HSO4 on the SCR performance of the catalysts, the decomposition temperature of NH4HSO4 was estimated. It was observed that the NH4HSO4-deposited Fe2O3 catalyst showed lower NO x conversion than the fresh one at temperatures of ≤250 °C, demonstrating that the decomposition temperature of NH4HSO4 was higher than 250 °C. In contrast, minimal variations were observed in the NO x conversion efficiencies for the SmO x -doped catalysts with or without NH4HSO4 deposition at temperatures of ≥250 °C, indicating the complete decomposition of NH4HSO4 at 250 °C and confirming the promotional effect of SmO x on NH4HSO4 decomposition [120]. Leveraging from the same method, the addition of Sb2O5 to Fe2O3 was also discovered to decrease the decomposition temperature of NH4HSO4 from approximately 300 °C to 250 °C [58]. With the exception of metal oxides, the catalyst support, activated carbon (AC), was modified with oxygen-containing functional groups through the treatment with (NH4)2S2O8, which was also found to lower the decomposition temperature of ammonia bisulfate [46]. As for the detailed reasons, limited information was available, which still needs to be investigated so as to provide theoretical guidance for the optimization of the present catalysts or the development of next-generation catalysts. As a typical factor to influence the physicochemical properties of the catalysts, employing the rational synthesis method has been proven to promote the decomposition of ammonia bisulfate. For instance, compared with the Mn-Fe/ZSM-5 composite prepared using the co-precipitation method, the one synthesized via the precipitation-chemical vapor deposition technique showed enhanced ammonia bisulfate decomposition behavior at temperatures of 200–400 °C owing to the abundance of isolated Fe3+ with high flexibility on the catalyst surface [121]. Apart from the factors from the catalysts themselves, tuning the compositions of the working gases is also proven as another effective strategy to promote the decomposition of ammonia bisulfate. As NO2 was introduced, its high reactivity would facilitate the consumption of NH4 + in ammonia bisulfate through the “fast SCR”-like pathways, which could more effectively recover the porous structure and surface area of the catalysts [118,122]. Moreover, its higher oxidative ability than O2 also efficiently re-oxidized the reduced metal cations, thereby accelerating the regeneration of active metal cations. 5.2 Inhibiting the adsorption of SO2 Generally, the deposition of ammonia bisulfate and the formation of metal sulfate can be regarded as the SO2-related reactions, with the adsorption of SO2 constituting the first step. Given that the adsorption of SO2 is inhibited, the formation of metal sulfate and its negative effects on the SCR reaction would be reduced. Considering the acid properties of SO2 molecules, the basic acid sites would participate in the SO2 adsorption process. Therefore, optimizing the dispersion of the active components, enhancing the acidity at the expense of the basicity, and tuning the electronic properties of the catalytically active cationic sites, can decrease the adsorption of SO2 to some extent. For the first modification strategy, optimization of the catalyst micro-morphology or textural structures was the commonly used technique. The typical example is the Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts synthesized using different methods [123]. With regard to the sample prepared with the mixed solvents of water and methanol (Fe-ZSM-5/WM), a slight decline in NO x conversion from ∼74 % to 69 % was observed as 200 ppm SO2 was introduced, while the NO x conversion declined by ∼18 % for the sample synthesized using methanol as the solvent (Fe-ZSM-5/M). The high sensitivity to SO2 of Fe-ZSM-5/M in the presence of SO2 was due to the concentrated Fe species outside the pore structure, which were much easier to react with SO2, forming stable sulfate species. Conversely, a better dispersion inside and outside the zeolite was detected for Fe-ZSM-5/WM, which reduced the formation of sulfate species, thus exhibiting the increased resistance to SO2 poisoning. Considering the low affinity of V2O5 to SO2, a thin layer of V2O5 was coated onto the Mn-Fe/attapulgite surface, forming the Mn-Fe/ATP@V core-shell catalysts [108]. Together with the improved acidity, the touch between SO2 and Fe2O3/MnO2 was inhibited, which reduced the generation of metal sulfates, thus ensuring the stability in the presence of SO2. With the protective effect of mesoporous SiO2 shell and SiO x -TiO2 shell, the adsorption of SO2 molecules onto the catalyst surface was inhibited, thereby weakening the interactions between the active FeO x in the inner core materials and SO2 [124,125]. Consequently, the catalysts could stably operate in SO2-containing feed gas. From the aspects of mass transfer, Zhao et al. constructed spherical chrysanthemum-like porous Fe2O3-Al2O3-WO3 catalysts. Because of the facilitated mass transfer of gas molecules and the sufficiently dispersed active components, SO2 was prone to directly passing through the catalyst particles rather than being adsorbed onto the active sites, thus having the active species Fe2O3 somehow preserved for the deNO x processes (Fig. 6 (a)) [126]. It is general that catalyst surface acid sites could be classified into Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites. Among them, the Brønsted acid sites precautioned against the poisoning of SO2 [127]. Thus, increasing the density of Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface seems to be an effective method to improve the sulfur resistance of the catalysts. Thanks to their superior acidity, the introduction of foreign metal sulfates would introduce abundant Brønsted acid sites on Fe2O3 surface. The pe-generated Fe2(SO4)3 would inhibit the interactions between SO2 and catalyst active centers. Moreover, the additionally introduced transition or rare earth metal cations might act as the secondary active sites for reactant adsorption and activation, thereby leading to an enhancement in the sulfur resistance of the Fe2O3 catalyst [109,116]. Similarly, the novel acidity enabled WO3 to be the appropriate promoters for the SCR catalysts. Upon the addition of WO3, an increase in the number of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites occurred, which somehow inhibited the adsorption of SO2 and the subsequent generation of sulfate anions. Together with the proper oxidative ability, comparatively satisfactory deNO x performance was achieved with SO2 [128–130]. Furthermore, Wang et al. used SO4 2- and WO3 to co-modify the FeO x -TiO2 catalyst. Via the DFT method, SO2 and NO were discovered to be adsorbed onto the Fe sites, while Ti, Fe, W, and sulfate sites were responsible for the adsorption of NH3. Compared with the virgin FeO x -TiO2 composite, the co-addition of WO3 and SO4 2- induced an increased SO2 adsorption energy from −1.675 eV to −1.213 eV, demonstrating that SO2 displayed weakened affinity to the Fe sites, thereby slowing down the sulfation process of the active components (Fig. 6(b)) [101]. Replacing WO3 and sulfates, MoO3 and heteropoly acid with strong acid properties were also used to enhance the SO2 tolerance of the Fe2O3 catalysts through the repulsion force from the abundant surface acid sites [30,99,131]. Given that the adsorption of NO/NH3 and SO2 on the catalyst surface was recognized as the chemisorption process, the migration of electrons between reactant molecules and catalyst surface atoms typically occurred. Therefore, apart from the enhancement in acidity, tuning the electronic properties of the catalytically active cationic sites could be an alternative strategy to improve the SO2-tolerant ability of the catalysts. Through doping sulfur atoms, the electronic interaction of short-range Fe-O coordination of the Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts was well modulated. Specifically, the doped S atoms existed as SO4 2- residing at subsurface TiO6 locations, which exerted strong electronic perturbation to TiO2, causing a net charge transfer from Fe2O3 to TiO2 via increased short-range Fe-O coordination. This electronic effect weakened the charge transfer from Fe2O3 to TiO2. As a charge acceptor molecule, SO2 adsorption was greatly weakened and SO2 oxidation to sulfate was mostly prevented. Apparently, nearly 100 % NO x conversion was maintained for the S-doped samples within 360 min, while a decline in NO x conversion from ∼70 % to ∼58 % was presented for the unmodified Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 6(c)) [111]. Using a similar strategy, the addition of TiO2 would make the electrons around Fe3+ migrate toward Ti4+, which strengthened the electron-deficient tendency of Fe3+. Compared with SO2, NH3 with electron donation properties was preferentially adsorbed by Fe3+. This SO2 adsorption inhibition endowed the TiO2-incorporated Fe2O3 catalysts with enhanced SO2 resistance, with >90 % NO x conversion maintained during the entire SO2 deactivation cycle (Fig. 6(d)) [115]. 5.3 Introducing sacrificial sites to protect Fe sites Considering the inevitable formation of metal sulfates through the strong interactions between SO2 and metal oxides, it is also effective to introduce certain foreign metal oxides to alleviate the sulfation of the active phase Fe2O3, which improves the SO2 resistance of the catalysts at the expense of the added metal oxides. Herein, adding some foreign metal oxides that have greater affinity to SO2 forming the mixed oxide-like compounds and constructing a core-shell structure with outer sacrificial sites are the rational strategies. For the former strategy, transition metal oxides and rare earth metal oxides like CoO x and PrO x are the commonly used additives. With regard to the pristine α-Fe2O3 catalyst, Jin et al. used CoO x for modification. It was found that when 50 ppm SO2 was added into the feed gas, the NO x conversion of the pristine α-Fe2O3 decreased from 95.6 % to 91.5 % after 7 h of the reaction. As the concentration of SO2 increased to 100 ppm, the NO x conversion continually decreased to 87.8 % and remained stable within 8 h. Further increasing the SO2 concentration to 150 ppm, the NO x conversion continually declined to 75.3 %. After introducing Co3O4 into α-Fe2O3, the NO x conversion reached 93.9 % during the whole SO2 deactivation cycle, demonstrating the marked enhancement in SO2 resistance. This was because Co3O4 in Co-doped catalyst could be converted to CoSO4, which showed good catalytic activity for the NH3-SCR reactions. And through the interactions between Co3O4 and CoSO4, the catalyst showed satisfactory deNO x performance even in the presence of SO2 [106]. In addition to their strong SO2 affinity, certain rare earth metal oxides, including PrO x , CeO x , and SmO x , have also been shown to serve as highly effective promoters. These materials enhance catalytic performance by increasing surface area, boosting NH3 adsorption capacity, and elevating the quantity of chemically active oxygen species. When PrO x was introduced, SO2 was more likely to react with the Pr species to produce praseodymium sulfate, which protected the Fe and Mn active sites and made the catalyst more active with SO2. Moreover, the stabilized SO4 2- also functioned as the Brønsted acid sites, which increased the acidity of the catalysts and inhibited the adsorption of SO2, hence leaving the active components preserved (Fig. 7 (a)) [113]. The incorporation of SmO x enhanced SO2 stabilization through its strong affinity for sulfate formation (Sm2(SO4)3), thereby protecting the active MnO x and FeO x sites for deNO x reactions. Remarkably, after 10 h of SO2 exposure, the modified catalyst maintained ∼90 % NO x conversion, a 50 % improvement over the unmodified MnFeO x catalyst [132]. Also, the preferential sulfation of CeO x protected Fe2O3 from sulfation while maintaining the high reactivities of the NH4 + and NH2 species. Particularly, the SCR reaction following the E-R mechanism largely enhanced the SO2 tolerance due to the absence of the competitive behaviors between sulfates and nitrates/nitrites [133]. Apart from the protective effects of the sacrificial sites provided from mesoporous TiO2 (m-TiO2), the interactions between HSO4 - in ammonia bisulfate and Brønsted acid sites from m-TiO2 impaired the binding energy between NH4 + and HSO4 -, leaving Fe sites preserved for the adsorption and activation of NH3 and NO Apparently, >90 % NO x conversion was retained within 60 h for the m-TiO2-modified Fe2O3 catalysts, whereas ∼50 % NO x conversion was presented for the virgin Fe2O3 (Fig. 7(b)) [134]. Additionally, some researchers constructed the core-shell materials to improve the SO2 resistance. Herein, the shell material always served as the sacrificial sites, with the core material primarily responsible for the adsorption and activation of the reactants. When coating a thin layer of mesoporous CeO2 onto the Fe/Beta and FeMo/Beta composites forming the Fe/Beta@CeO2 and FeMo/Beta@CeO2 core-shell catalysts, the CeO2 layer functioned as an adsorbent to stabilize SO2 from feed gas, which suppressed the generation of sulfate species and their coverage onto the catalyst surface active sites. Moreover, the stabilization of sulfate species would increase the acidity of the catalyst, causing an inhibitory effect on the touch of SO2 to active sites and thereby reducing the sensitivity to SO2 (Fig. 7(c)) [135,136]. TiO2 is a commonly used shell material because of its controllable coating process and tunable micro-structures [137–139]. Owing to its abundant surface basic hydroxyl groups that showed great affinity to SO2, TiO2 was also used as the sacrificial shell material to protect the inner active components [140]. Specifically, TiO2 modified the electronic structure of the catalyst, causing the electron cloud density of Ti toward Fe and Mn. As a result, electron-deficient Ti sites were formed, which were preferentially attacked by SO2. Furthermore, introducing Ti created bridging hydroxyl groups with oxidizing capabilities on the catalyst surface. Under the synergistic effect of coordination-unsaturated Ti sites and bridging hydroxyl groups, SO2 was oxidized to sulfates and retained on the TiO2 shell, thereby protecting the Fe and Mn sites from poisoning and contributing to the enhanced SO2-tolerant ability [141]. Similar with TiO2, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) also showed an abundance of surface hydroxyl sites, which were primarily responsible for the capture of SO2 from the feed gas and beneficial for the improvement in the catalyst sulfur resistance [50]. Apparently, the Fe-Mn@CNTs exhibited excellent stability under a harsh gas condition with 1000 ppm SO2 and 20 % H2O; during the 20-hour sulfur deactivation cycle, minimal variations in the catalyst’s NO x conversion were observed [142]. 5.4 Promoting the generation of active nitrates When exposed to the SO2-containing feed gas, the active nitrate species are competitively generated with sulfates, which cuts off the proceeding of the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) pathways, thereby inducing a declined NO x conversion efficiency. For this reason, promoting the adsorption of NO x and the formation of active nitrate and NO2 species to ensure the progression of the l-H mechanism with sulfate species can be regarded as another effective strategy to achieve satisfactory SO2 durability. Similar with the abovementioned three strategies, introducing foreign metal oxides, optimizing the synthesis method, and constructing specific micro-structures are the generally used methods. To some extent, this strategy is consistent with that related to the inhibited adsorption of SO2. Given the competitive adsorption of NO and SO2 onto the active sites, the inhibited SO2 adsorption would leave more sites preserved for NO adsorption and nitrate/nitrite generation, thus favoring the progression of the l-H reaction pathway and retaining the comparatively high NO x conversion [101,111,143]. Given that the properties of the catalyst surface active sites predominantly determined the adsorption behaviors of the reactant molecules, having their properties rationally modified might be an effective method for the efficient adsorption of NO in the presence of SO2. Simply, this issue could be addressed through optimizing the chemical formula of the catalysts, like doping certain transition or rare earth metal oxides. Under the action of the added ZrO2, both the increased availability and reducibility of Mn4+ and Mn3+ were obtained, which was favorable for the adsorption and activation of NO on the Fe-Mn/Ti catalyst surface. Compared with the unmodified catalyst, more nitrates and NO2 were formed in the presence of SO2 on Fe-Mn/Ti-Zr, with the proceeding of the l-H reaction pathway less inhibited with Zr additive [144]. CeO2, TiO2, Sm2O3, and Co3O4, with either excellent redox features or certain basicity, were also discovered to weaken the negative effect of SO2 on the adsorption of NO x , promote the formation of active nitrate and nitrite species, and ensure the l-H reaction pathway with the help of abundant reactive chemisorbed oxygen species [145–147]. Specifically, through the synergistic effects between CeO x and FeO x , Ce-O-Fe species were present in the catalyst. The local electronic environment of Fe species was altered through the electron confinement effect, which improved the mobility of the catalyst surface reactive oxygen. After sulfation, the Ce-O-Fe-SO4 2- species kept the electron transfer between Ce and Fe species. Simultaneously, ample active oxygen species still remained on the catalyst surface despite the action of SO2, which retained the redox cycle and allowed the NO molecules to be effectively adsorbed. Thus, the progression of the L-H mechanism was ensured even in the presence of SO2, leaving the SCR reaction occurring successively (Fig. 8 (a)) [148]. Taking advantage of mesoporous structures, Tang et al. had a thin layer of amorphous TiO2 coated on the SBA-15 surface, forming the Fe/Ti@Si catalyst. With the increase in the coating amount of amorphous TiO2, the ratio of Brønsted acid sites to Lewis acid sites increased. Coupled with the increased specific surface area, minimal effects of SO2 were exerted on the adsorption and activation of NO, making the l-H reaction pathway hardly prohibited. This enhancement was responsible for the superior sulfur resistance of the Fe/Ti@Si composite compared with the conventional Fe/Ti supported catalyst (Fig. 8(b)) [149]. To be another predominant factor, optimizing the preparation process would contribute to the diverse physical structures and chemical properties of the catalysts owing to the different chemicals and conditions employed. Given proper operation, the generation of NO complex could be somehow ensured despite the presence of SO2. Combining the acid leaching and reprecipitation methods, the red mud was activated and used as the NH3-SCR catalyst. For the sample treated in an acid solution with a concentration of 3.1 mol/L, the strongest reducibility, largest amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen, and medium surface acidity were obtained. Given these benefits, more NO can be adsorbed and oxidized on the catalyst to generate an increased availability of nitrate species in the presence of SO2. Therefore, the l-H reaction mechanism was efficiently obeyed for the optimal catalyst during the SCR reactions with SO2, therefore alleviating the suppression of SO2 on NO x reduction to a certain extent. Apparently, >80 % NO x conversion was maintained within 6 h during the SO2 deactivation cycle (Fig. 8(c)) [150]. Wang et al. employed a sustainable two-stage air oxidation (TAO) method to prepare the Fe-Mn/biochar catalyst and found that the abundance of Brønsted acid sites greatly contributed to the enhanced adsorption of NH3/NO and helped NO gain dominance in competitive adsorption with SO2, hence endowing the catalyst prepared using the TAO method to exhibit better SO2 resistance compared with the samples synthesized using the conventional high temperature treatment and chemical activation techniques (Fig. 8(d)) [151]. As a conclusion, the abovementioned techniques have been proven to effectively enhance the sulfur resistance of the catalysts with proper operation. And up to now, the combination of the SO2 resistance enhancement strategies has also been sometimes employed for the stable operation of the catalysts under SO2-containing conditions, for instance, the combination of accelerating the decomposition of ammonia bisulfate, inhibiting the adsorption of SO2, and promoting the generation of active nitrates. Even though great efforts have been conducted on addressing this issue, a downward trend in NO x conversion in the presence of SO2 could still be observed in most cases. That is to say, only slowing down the deactivation process, rather than completely eliminating the deactivation phenomena, could be realized based on the present research results, highlighting the demand for further research on fully addressing the sulfur-poisoning challenge. 6 Regeneration of the sulfated catalysts While the strategies mentioned earlier can improve catalyst stability in SO2-containing flue gases to some degree, they only slow, rather than prevent, deactivation. Prolonged exposure to SO2 will inevitably lead to performance degradation. To recycle and reuse the deactivated catalysts, regeneration of poisoned catalysts becomes necessary, with thermal treatment and aqueous washing being the most common approaches for sulfur-poisoned catalysts. Thermal regeneration involves heating sulfated catalysts in either inert or oxygen-rich atmospheres. Due to their thermal instability, ammonium sulfate deposits decompose during heating, partially restoring pore structure accessibility [41]. Wu et al. demonstrated that treating catalysts at 400 °C under N2 for 2 h could recover some activity by marginally increasing surface area and active metal cation concentration [152]. Notably, the comparatively low treatment temperature cannot make the deposited metal sulfate species fully decomposed, thereby inducing the incomplete recovery of the activity [153]. By contrast, the heat treatment at 650 °C in air for 3 h could lead to the complete decomposition of the deposited sulfate salts, either ammonia sulfates or metal sulfates, on FeCu/AEI catalyst, which led to the similar deNO x performance with the fresh sample. Even though the heat treatment temperature was higher than the calcination temperature (550 °C), the satisfactory stability of the zeolite support could still stabilize the loaded active components, hence bringing out a good deNO x performance [154]. Chang et al. further found FeW/Ti catalysts regenerated more completely than CuW/Ti or MnW/Ti counterparts at 400 °C (air, 30 min), attributing this to their lower metal-sulfate-to-ammonium-sulfate ratio [155]. Since metal sulfates exhibit higher thermal stability, their predominance necessitates higher regeneration temperatures. While thermal methods effectively remove ammonium sulfates, they struggle with refractory metal sulfates, Specifically, their complete elimination risks damaging catalyst integrity through excessive heating. Aqueous regeneration employs deionized water or dilute acid washes. For FeO x -based catalysts, literature remains sparse. Only Duan et al. clarified that stirring water washing and sulfur acid washing could effectively remove both ammonia sulfates and metal sulfates adhered to the catalyst surface, making the poisoned catalysts recover to its original activity as the fresh one [156]. However, these methods leach active metal cations, causing cumulative performance loss with repeated regeneration cycles. This underscores the pressing need for developing more efficient, gentle regeneration techniques, a key research frontier in SCR technology critical for advancing FeO x catalyst applications. 7 Conclusions and perspectives Strategic optimization, including accelerating NH4HSO4 decomposition, inhibiting SO2 adsorption, introducing sacrificial sites to protect active Fe centers, and promoting active nitrate formation, can significantly enhance the durability of FeO x -based catalysts in SO2- or SO2/H2O-containing environments within specific temperature ranges. These advances provide critical insights for scaling up FeO x -based SCR catalysts for industrial applications. Despite the significant progress achieved in developing SO2-resistant FeO x -based catalysts for NO x reduction, further research is essential to advance next-generation materials with superior SO2 durability. The following key research directions are identified: (1) High SO2 concentration and long-term operation challenges: While modified catalysts demonstrate satisfactory SO2 resistance at (2) concentrations below 500 ppm in laboratory settings, industrial waste gases often contain SO2 levels exceeding 1000 ppm. Laboratory sulfur resistance testing typically lasts only several hours to tens of hours - significantly shorter than the years-long continuous exposure experienced in actual engineering applications. The long-term stability of current catalysts under such harsh conditions still remains unclear, necessitating further investigation and potential optimization of their formulations and structures. (3) Impact of SO3 and complex gas mixtures: Real waste gases frequently contain trace amounts of SO3 (tens of ppm), which exhibits higher reactivity than SO2. The effects of SO3 or SO2/SO3/H2O mixtures on catalyst performance require thorough evaluation. If SO3 proves detrimental, dedicated anti-poisoning strategies must be developed. Furthermore, actual flue gas contains additional components including HCl, alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, and heavy metals. The impact of these complex gas mixtures on the SCR performance of FeO x -based catalysts requires further investigation to fully assess their practical applicability. (4) Mass transfer-reaction kinetics coupling mechanism: Current research predominantly focuses on adsorption and reaction processes while neglecting mass transfer dynamics. Enhanced SO2 mass transfer can be achieved by enlarging catalyst pore diameter and modifying chemical composition is able to weaken SO2-metal oxide interactions. This optimization promotes SO2 passage through the catalyst bed rather than reaction with active sites, as evidenced by extended breakthrough times in SO2 adsorption profiles. Simultaneously, strategic tuning of catalyst components maintains effective NH3 and NO x adsorption/activation, preserving SCR reactivity even under SO2 exposure. Future studies should prioritize the interplay between mass transfer and reaction kinetics. (5) Advanced characterization techniques: Most mechanistic studies rely on ex situ methods, limiting insights into real-time catalyst behavior. Systematic integration of in situ and ex situ characterization is critical to elucidate poisoning mechanisms under operational conditions. (6) Low-temperature deactivation kinetics and thermodynamics: Limited data exist on the kinetics of catalyst deactivation at lower temperatures (<200 °C) in SO2/H2O environments, as well as the thermodynamics of sulfate species formation during the SCR reactions. Addressing these gaps is vital for optimizing FeO x -based catalysts for practical applications. (7) Economic analysis: Once a novel catalyst capable of stable operation under real-world conditions is developed, a thorough economic analysis must be conducted to evaluate system costs. These findings can then guide targeted optimizations in the catalyst preparation process, such as refining molding methods or selecting more cost-effective molding agents, without compromising deNO x efficiency. Such optimizations are critical for achieving significant cost reductions while maintaining satisfactory performance. coredata.dc:description: The selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) is a well-established technology for controlling NO x emissions from industrial sources. FeO x -based catalysts have been extensively studied due to their favorable thermal stability, natural abundance, environmental compatibility, and effective deNO x performance under ideal conditions. However, the presence of SO2 in actual flue gases poses a significant barrier to the widespread commercial adoption of the FeO x -based catalysts. During the reaction process, SO2 interacts with NH3 or catalyst active sites, leading to the formation of ammonia bisulfate/sulfate (NH4HSO4/(NH4)2SO4) and relatively inert metal sulfates. These byproducts are the primary causes of the observed decline in NO x conversion efficiency, underscoring the critical need to develop next-generation catalysts with enhanced SO2 resistance. This review provides a comprehensive overview of recent advancements in FeO x -based catalysts for the SCR reactions in SO2-containing environments. The process of SO2 adsorption on Fe2O3 is first summarized, as it represents the initial step in catalyst sulfur deactivation. When SO2 interacts with NH₃ or active catalyst components, the resulting ammonium sulfates or metal sulfates can either enhance or impair catalytic performance, a topic explored in detail later. Given that H2O is a common component in industrial flue gases, its role in accelerating catalyst deactivation alongside SO2 is also clarified. To address this significant deactivation challenge, established strategies for improving the SO2 resistance of SCR catalysts are discussed in Section 5. While these approaches can slow deactivation, they cannot prevent it entirely. Therefore, Section 6 covers advances in regenerating spent catalysts for recycling and reuse. Finally, this review highlights the urgent need for further improvements in catalyst durability under real-world flue gas conditions to achieve more efficient and sustainable NO x emission control.
